repnme.cdata!:
Congo, Democratic Republic of - Emergency
            Multisector Rehabilitation and Reconstruction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Multisector
            Rehabilitation and Reconstruction Project for Congo,
            Democratic Republic of were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: a distinction needs to be made between emergency
            operations caused by natural disasters and those in a
            post-conflict context. In the first case, institutional
            capacity and policy tend not be major issues. In the second
            case, because of the destruction caused by conflicts, the
            process starts off with much lower levels of capacity and
            knowledge. This argues for the need to include institutional
            reforms, capacity building and sector strategy formulation
            as was done in this project in order to start laying the
            foundations for the future. Strong commitment from
            management in terms of resources and continuity within the
            task team is a key determination of successful
            implementation. The use of Non-governmental organizations
            proved to be an effective and efficient way of
            implementation the social activities at the grass root
            level. This should serve as a lesson and good precedent.
            Even in emergency situations, an effort should be made to
            address sustainability issues at the project or program
            design stage. If not done, the investments made could be
            jeopardized over the long term. If this is not discussed
            during project preparation and appraisal, it should be
            included as part of early implementation activities as it
            was done in the project case.

repnme.cdata!:
Congo, Democratic Republic of - Emergency
            Multisector Rehabilitation and Reconstruction Project :
            second additional financing

abstracts.cdata!:
This paper is for an additional grant to
            the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) for the Emergency
            Multi-sector Rehabilitation and Reconstruction Project which
            was approved in June 2002. The additional grant would help
            finance the costs associated with completion of certain
            priority activities included in the original Project scope,
            which are subject to unanticipated cost overruns and
            financing gaps. The focus of the support will be for: (i)
            urgent rehabilitation of key elements of electricity sector
            infrastructure, and (ii) project execution and supervision
            across the infrastructure component of the Project in order
            to ensure that activities are completed by the Project
            closing date. As a result, the expected outcome of the
            proposed second Additional Financing is that: (i) the
            original development objectives of the electricity sector
            component continue to be achieved, namely to rehabilitate
            and reconstruct the electricity supply networks serving
            major cities, and (ii) that overall execution and
            supervision of the Project continues smoothly until Project completion.

repnme.cdata!:
Congo, Democratic Republic of - Emergency
            Multisector Rehabilitation and Reconstruction Project :
            resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Multisector Rehabilitation
            and Reconstruction Project will rebuild critical
            infrastructure, develop agriculture, and deliver social
            services to develop communities within the Republic of
            Congo. The resettlement plan report anticipates potential
            resettlement impacts and discusses measures to mitigate
            them, as follows : visits to the displaced households after
            resettlement to ensure that their living standards have been
            restored to their pre-displacement levels; prevent squatters
            for resettling in the infrastructure; ensure that displaced
            person do not resettle in the buffer zone around the erosion
            control infrastructure; and prevent displaced people from
            resettling in areas also affected by erosion. Also, project
            affected peoples (PAP) will receive compensation for their
            land, house, fruit trees and food crops, and moving support
            and if necessary monetary support.

repnme.cdata!:
Congo, Democratic Republic of - Emergency
            Multisector Rehabilitation and Reconstruction Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment for
            the Emergency Multisector Rehabilitation and Reconstruction
            Project for the Republic of Congo, which rebuilds critical
            infrastructure, develops agriculture, and delivers social
            services to develop the community. The report anticipates
            negative environmental impacts and discusses measures to
            mitigate them. Among the risks and proposed mitigations it
            discusses are the following: Reduce noise. During
            construction, protect against the emanation of toxic gases
            and the risks of inhaling particulate matter. When
            transporting materials, systematically spray material or use
            tarpaulin on trucks, spray land routes, and limit vehicle
            speed. Locate concrete and coal works far from human
            habitations. Regulate vehicle emissions, control traffic,
            and require motorist to install muffler equipment. All open
            air burning must be preauthorized, and the project manager
            must approve incineration of ordinary garbage and industrial
            waste. Protect against soil degradation due to erosion,
            vegetative loss, and interference with protected species by
            removing, storing, and replacing topsoil; replanting areas
            after use; and bio-regenerating soil polluted by accidental
            dumping. Alleviate adverse effects to the quality of surface
            and underground water by avoiding dumping and controlling
            waste disposal, controlling vehicles traversing the
            watercourses, avoiding excavation during the rainy season,
            avoiding the storage of hazardous materials near
            watercourses, installing filtration barriers, regularly
            maintaining equipment and machinery, avoiding oil spills,
            and managing water use. Put in place a compensation system
            according to agreed upon standards for the destruction of
            fruit trees and crops, buildings, and real and personal
            property. Set up a forest management program, and control
            hunting and launch a preventative information campaign to
            reduce interference and destruction of animals. Protect
            workers and the general population from infectious diseases
            and pollution by treating water and reducing, separating,
            recycling, storing and disposing of waste according to
            agreement, and providing information on disease prevention;
            from accidents by securing buildings; and from fire hazards
            by acquiring equipment. Lastly, the project will protect
            cultural heritage and religious sites and monuments and/or
            compensate the population as required.

            services to develop the community. The report anticipates
            negative environmental impacts and discusses measures to
            mitigate them. Among the risks and proposed mitigations it
            discusses are the following: Reduce noise. During
            construction, protect against the emanation of toxic gases
            and the risks of inhaling particulate matter. When
            transporting materials, systematically spray material or use
            tarpaulin on trucks, spray land routes, and limit vehicle
            speed. Locate concrete and coal works far from human
            habitations. Regulate vehicle emissions, control traffic,
            and require motorist to install muffler equipment. All open
            air burning must be preauthorized, and the project manager
            must approve incineration of ordinary garbage and industrial
            waste. Protect against soil degradation due to erosion,
            vegetative loss, and interference with protected species by
            removing, storing, and replacing topsoil; replanting areas
            after use; and bio-regenerating soil polluted by accidental
            dumping. Alleviate adverse effects to the quality of surface
            and underground water by avoiding dumping and controlling
            waste disposal, controlling vehicles traversing the
            watercourses, avoiding excavation during the rainy season,
            avoiding the storage of hazardous materials near
            watercourses, installing filtration barriers, regularly
            maintaining equipment and machinery, avoiding oil spills,
            and managing water use. Put in place a compensation system
            according to agreed upon standards for the destruction of
            fruit trees and crops, buildings, and real and personal
            property. Set up a forest management program, and control
            hunting and launch a preventative information campaign to
            reduce interference and destruction of animals. Protect
            workers and the general population from infectious diseases
            and pollution by treating water and reducing, separating,
            recycling, storing and disposing of waste according to
            agreement, and providing information on disease prevention;
            from accidents by securing buildings; and from fire hazards
            by acquiring equipment. Lastly, the project will protect
            cultural heritage and religious sites and monuments and/or
            compensate the population as required.
